Name: Figure of a female carved in relief
Description: Torso and right arm from a shallow relief carving of a female figure in fine drapery, competently carved in bone (probably, rather than ivory), from the great city founded by the Roman Emperor Hadrian at the site where his lover Antinous drowned in the Nile, and named after him Antinoopolis. The city became the dominant provincial city of Upper Egypt, and flourished throughout the Byzantine Period.
